awd_titl_txt: CEDAR Workshop 2018 - 2020 and Community Web Pages and Email Services
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will fund the annual summer CEDAR (Coupling, Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions) workshop for the three summers of 2018 to 2020.  CEDAR is a broad-based, community-initiated, upper atmospheric research program with the targeted goal of understanding the behavior of atmospheric regions from the middle atmosphere upward through the thermosphere and ionosphere into the exosphere in terms of coupling, energetics, chemistry, and dynamics on regional and global scales. These processes are related to the sources of perturbations that propagate upward from the lower atmosphere as well as a result of solar radiation, particle inputs and electric fields from above. Traditionally the CEDAR meeting has been regarded as the foremost workshop for the CEDAR community of over 1,850 people worldwide. The activities supported within this program combine observations, theory and modeling. Additional services are provided throughout the year to keep the database of names, addresses and emails current, as well as supporting community unity through wiki web pages and community emails.

The CEDAR Workshop and associated community services would be managed by the UCAR Cooperative Programs for the Advancement of Earth System Science (CPAESS). The mission of CPAESS is geared toward preparing and training the next generation of weather and climate scientific leaders and workforce by supporting effective and collaborative fellowships, visitor, and workshop programs that meet emerging training and research needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals are to organize and hold the annual Coupling, Energetics, and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR) Workshops and administer the student travel funds for the meeting. CEDAR has always had a strong emphasis on attracting and retaining students and training the next generation scientists.

In 2021 a virtual CEDAR workshop was organized. While CEDAR 2021 had a venue in Colorado Springs due to COVID it was decided that no in-person meeting will be held. The CEDAR workshop schedule was similar to in-person meetings with plenary sessions, individual workshops, student day, networking events, and poster sessi with competition. The workshop days were shorter to accommodate the different time zones. The plenary session time was reduced while still allowing 2h individual workshops. In addition, no new Grand Challenge workshop was selected in 2021.

The CEDAR workshop could offer a platform for scientific exchange and support the student’s research by providing a forum to discuss their research and offering networking events such as a panel discussion and lunch with a scientist. Registration was free and approximately 839 people from 42 countries participated (roughly double of an in-person workshop). There was an almost even distribution between students (28%), early career (18%), mid-career (20%) and senior scientists (29%) among the participants. The non-scientist participants increased compared to last year to 5% (in 2020 it was 3%). The international participation is very high for the virtual meeting with 29% of undergraduates, 53% of graduate students, and between 25% to 45% for the other career stages. Having a large international participation fosters the scientific exchange and collaboration beyond the US. The US participation was larger than for in-person meetings with 518 US participants from approximately 120 different institutions among them 57 US-universities and colleges. No registration fee was charged.

The community was very active and organized 33 individual workshops. The plenary session included invited science highlights as well as dedicated highlights from early career scientists. Notably in 2021 the plenary session included a presentation by Dr. Brandon Jones (NSF) about education and diversity programs at NSF to raise awareness in the CEDAR community about diversity, equity, and inclusion. Using Slido to ask questions during the plenary session (webinar style) increased the number of asked questions compared to in-person meetings. The individual workshop were normal zoom sessions which allowed for direct communication. Slack was used for additional communication.

The success of the 2021 virtual workshop was made possible by the community and highlights that the CEDAR workshop is the premier workshop for ground-based and space-based upper atmosphere researchers, community planning, and for students in the US but also abroad. 

The grant provides additional support to design a new CEDAR website to replace the old wiki one which had to be taken offline in December 2021 because of security concerns. The steering committee and CPAESS work on the content, structure, and design of the new CEDAR webpages.
